This PR involves several parts of the change, with some of them involves minor change while others need some drastic changes. 

Some of the remaining issues include, I list them directly as the comments get long:

-  indentation issues (need 2-space indent), 
-  miss complete documents for arguments of functions(especially those that are in the include).
-  some comments are still in the fly (the use of Buffer reference in the code) 
-  RELAY_LOG, a bit redundant feature, consider use ```DLOG(INFO)``` instead
-  Move include/runtime/memory_manager.h into src/runtime for now as this interface could still be debatable, as per @junrushao1994 

While many of them are minor things, the conversation could drag longer. To make the merge smoothly in the incoming week. I propose we do it in four steps:

- runtime related
   - memory_manager @icemelon9 
   - object related change to PackedFunc etc. @jroesch 
- runtime/vm
   - The VM runtime changes, without compiler @jroesch 
   - No regression test cases, but need to confirm the public interface and docs
- relay/backend/vm @jroesch @wweic 
   - The VM compiler related changes.
   - The regression tests case be added in the end.
- Docs about relay vm @jroesch 

The subsequent ones can be proposed as separate PRs, and rebase when necessary.

@tqchen This naming comes from pytorch pooling family： https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/_modules/torch/nn/modules/pooling.html  MXNet has a similar API for adaptive avg pooing: https://mxnet.apache.org/api/python/ndarray/contrib.html?highlight=adap#mxnet.ndarray.contrib.AdaptiveAvgPooling2D For now I don't see a more appropriate name in mainsteam DL frameworks. Also adaptive describes the behavior of this kind of pooling.

It's very likely due to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/topi/python/topi/mali/conv2d.py#L357

@tqchen 
After investigating generated lower stmt, I found a important difference:
In old version which has expected performance, this fused func has such a patten:
```
tvm_if_then_else((24512 <= ((((ax0.ax1.fused*4) + ax2) + -4) % 24528)), placeholder[(((((ax0.ax1.fused*4) + ax2) + -4) % 24528) % 16)],  ...
```
After Analyzer CanonicalSimplifier commit, it becomes:
```
tvm_if_then_else((24512 <= ((((ax0.ax1.fused*4) + ax2) + -466036) % 24528)), placeholder[((((((ax0.ax1.fused*4) + ax2) + -466036) % 24528) + -24512) % 16)],  ...
```
Two expressions have the same semantic but the latter one is more complicated. The original one has ```-4) % 24528)``` while currently it is ```-466036) % 24528)```. Since 466036 % 24528 = 4, this is not necessary. Also note in the ```% 24528) % 16)``` becomes ```% 24528) + -24512) % 16)```. Since 24512 % 16 = 0, this is not necessary either.
A lot of similar pattens happen in this func and it might be the problem. 

Since lowered stmt is very long, I put the complete stmt in gist: [old](https://gist.github.com/kevinthesun/7dfa5148efaecafe4f4b8bbb41e89e8e) and [new](https://gist.github.com/kevinthesun/1f19f422890ecc61744f16eda723639a)

I am using LLVM 9 +  ROCM 2.3

@masahi Yes, what I tested is the simplest one, you can try this Dockerfile on your host, which is segfault on my host:
```sh
FROM rocm/dev-ubuntu-18.04

ENV HIP_PLATFORM hcc
ENV PATH $PATH:/opt/rocm/bin:/usr/local/rocm/bin

RUN apt-get update && apt install -y --no-install-recommends git ca-certificates \
    python3-pip python3-wheel python3-setuptools python3-pytest python3-dev \
    vim less netcat-openbsd inetutils-ping curl patch iproute2 \
    g++ libpci3 libnuma-dev make file libelf-dev libboost-system-dev libboost-filesystem-dev \
    miopen-hip miopengemm hipblas rocrand hipsparse hip-thrust cxlactivitylogger rocfft rocprofiler-dev llvm-7-dev cmake \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

WORKDIR /root

RUN git clone https://github.com/dmlc/tvm --branch master --depth 1 --single-branch --recursive && \
    cd tvm && git submodule init && git submodule update

RUN mkdir -p tvm/build && cd tvm/build && cp ../cmake/config.cmake . && \
    sed -i 's/ROCM OFF/ROCM ON/g' config.cmake && \
    sed -i 's/LLVM OFF/LLVM ON/g' config.cmake && \
    cmake .. && make -j16

RUN pip3 install numpy tornado psutil xgboost numpy decorator attrs

ENV TVM_HOME=/root/tvm
ENV PYTHONPATH=$TVM_HOME/python:$TVM_HOME/topi/python:$TVM_HOME/nnvm/python

RUN curl -Ls https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/raw/master/tutorials/tensor_expr_get_started.py | sed 's/cuda/rocm/g' > tensor_expr_get_started.py
```

To build and run:
```sh
# [DOCKER BUILD]
docker build -t tvm-rocm --network=host .
# [RUN TEST]
docker run -it --privileged --network=host tvm-rocm python3 tensor_expr_get_started.py
```

And this is my output:
```sh
/root/docker$ docker run -it --privileged --network=host tvm-rocm python3 tensor_expr_get_started.py
<class 'tvm.tensor.Tensor'>
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```
It seems you need a newer LLVM. That error comes from LLVM, not TVM.

a function that doesn't depend on the object is better static, this avoid needs to create a Symbol in the backward pass in MXNet just to call this function. For NNVM is no change as there's a member calling the static, so API remains the same. Any concerns for merging @tqchen ?
FYI, I fixed this issue after changing the ndk version to v16

As I said in the last thread, creating a new Symbol won't be much of a problem, because structurally it is equivalent to ```vector<NodeEntry>```. It will also make the python interfacing easy, as Symbol itself is exposed in python. So there won't be too much performance gains you will get by making this change.
Thanks @jroesch @zhreshold @yzhliu , this is now merged

Is not about performance, it's more about semantics, there's no need to create a symbol when one wants to list the inputs from a graph. Did you check the link to the MXNet code that I was referring to? It's about interface segregation as in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SOLID
This is a minor change that doesn't affect your APIs.

Blocked on [https://github.com/dmlc/HalideIR/pull/57](https://github.com/dmlc/HalideIR/pull/57).

Summary of my main review comments:

- Currently, NDArray needs to be aware of Allocator, it does not have to be the case. Instead, we can implement allocator->Empty(args), which creates an empty NDArray using the allocator. This means that we need to create array creation logic into memory_manager.cc. 
  - The advantage is that the memory manager will become a plugin
- Consider, move memory manager related logic into src/vm, given that they are being used by vm and not necessarily static graph runtime.
try to change that to tvm.expr.Mul(a, b)

This could due to CanonicalSimplify for making a stronger assumption of simplifying the divisions and mod(having to make sure operands are positive). 

This is mainly because we make a different assumption about the division semantics(truncdiv vs floordiv)

For this particular case, we could enhance the simplifier to deduce that the operand before mod is indeed positive, I will attempt a fix in the incoming weeks and see how it goes

Some minor nits. After some thoughts, I personally do not like the fact that Node and Object system are separate.  Eventually, we want to merge them into a single node system, but still have a clear separation of compiler and runtime node objects.

For now, we could even reuse the NodeBase class for object(which allows the effective use of make_node). This may need to happen in a few months and I don't want to block the PR, but it might be helpful to keep that in mind when polishing this PR, e.g., the naming(XXXCell-> XXXNode?).

Possible way of unification, for reference:

- NodeBase contains a tag field 
- ASTNode subclass NodeBase, and has additional virtual functions for AST level support(attr travseral etc), the tags can dynamically allocated during runtime.
- Object is a subclass of NodeBase, with fixed tags.
It would be great if you can open a new thread in https://discuss.tvm.ai/, we encourage everyone to post on forum first :)

I believe this is a nit change that could go either way. 

The main problem I have about introducing the new API is will results in other questions, e.g. do we want to also add static APIs for other functions like ListInputNames? Should these static functions belong to Symbol at all given they are only related to nodes? 

As a lazy solution, I would rather avoid these questions by just creating a Symbol and call ListInputs, which is just fine.
This being said, if we just stop at adding this function, and add sufficient document to it, I am fine merging it in.
given that this question has evolved to more general discussions, I would recommend starting a conversation on https://discuss.tvm.ai/ :)
